description:
Unfortunately, there is no species known as "Citrobacter bitternis" in the scientific literature. Citrobacter is a genus of Gram-negative bacteria that belong to the family Enterobacteriaceae, but there is no documented species with the name "bitternis" associated with this genus.

Citrobacter species are commonly found in the environment, such as in soil, water, and the intestinal tracts of humans and animals. Some Citrobacter species are known to be opportunistic pathogens, meaning they can cause infections in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying medical conditions. However, without more specific information about the supposed "Citrobacter bitternis" species, I cannot provide a meaningful scientific description.

In general, Citrobacter bacteria are rod-shaped, motile, and capable of fermenting various carbohydrates. They are also known to be able to reduce nitrates and produce hydrogen sulfide. Further research would be needed to determine the characteristics and potential significance of a Citrobacter species with the name "bitternis," if such a species actually exists.
